content.body: Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders]: wpt.fyi says that https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/html/browsers/the-window-object/garbage-collection-and-browsing-contexts/discard_iframe_history_1.html passes only in Firefox, and when I try to align about:blank behavior with other browsers, the test starts behaving in Firefox the way it already behaves in Chrome. This strongly suggests we should change the test expectation, right? Do you recall if there's spec text to adjust as well?

content.body:
> <@hsivonen:mozilla.org> Sam Sneddon [:gsnedders]: wpt.fyi says that https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/html/browsers/the-window-object/garbage-collection-and-browsing-contexts/discard_iframe_history_1.html passes only in Firefox, and when I try to align about:blank behavior with other browsers, the test starts behaving in Firefox the way it already behaves in Chrome. This strongly suggests we should change the test expectation, right? Do you recall if there's spec text to adjust as well?

Specifically, AFAICT, interop says to remove the `+ 1` on this line: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/html/browsers/the-window-object/garbage-collection-and-browsing-contexts/discard_iframe_history_1-1.html#L11

content.body: Yes, that line looks quite suspect... loading a no-src (i.e. about:blank) iframe should not increase history length according to both the current spec and the upcoming rewrite (https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/6315)
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Yes, that line looks quite suspect... loading a no-src (i.e. about:blank) iframe should not increase history length according to both the current spec and the upcoming rewrite (https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/6315)

content.body: Oh, no, I misread, it's navigating...

content.body: The src-less srcdoc-less iframe is on its initial about:blank
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: The src-less srcdoc-less iframe is on its initial about:blank

content.body: Any navigation from the initial about:blank, per current and future spec, must be a replace navigation (does not increment history.length).
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Any navigation from the initial about:blank, per current and future spec, must be a replace navigation (does not increment history.length).

content.body: Domenic: I'm looking at `async iterable` support in Firefox, the WebIDL spec talks about a "end of iteration value", but it doesn't actually define what that looks like?

content.body: spec question about dedicated worker lifetimes: if dedicated worker A `postMessage()`s to dedicated worker B, can A die before B receives the message? if so, does the spec guarantee that B will receive the message?
content.formatted_body: spec question about dedicated worker lifetimes: if dedicated worker A postMessage()s to dedicated worker B, can A die before B receives the message? if so, does the spec guarantee that B will receive the message?

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: spec question about dedicated worker lifetimes: if dedicated worker A `postMessage()`s to dedicated worker B, can A die before B receives the message? if so, does the spec guarantee that B will receive the message?

spec question about dedicated worker lifetimes: if dedicated worker A postMessage()s to dedicated worker B, can A die before B receives the message? if so, does the spec guarantee that B will receive the message?

content.body: It seems like actual engines don't keep dedicated workers alive after their parent dedicated worker dies, but the spec is not 100% clear about this: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7840
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It seems like actual engines don't keep dedicated workers alive after their parent dedicated worker dies, but the spec is not 100% clear about this: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/7840

content.body: but going by the spec, and assuming that it was clear that dedicated worker B stays alive – `postMessage()` posts a task on B's event loop, so assuming that A dies after the `postMessage` call finishes, it can die before B receives it, but B will still receive it
content.formatted_body: but going by the spec, and assuming that it was clear that dedicated worker B stays alive – postMessage() posts a task on B's event loop, so assuming that A dies after the postMessage call finishes, it can die before B receives it, but B will still receive it

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: but going by the spec, and assuming that it was clear that dedicated worker B stays alive – `postMessage()` posts a task on B's event loop, so assuming that A dies after the `postMessage` call finishes, it can die before B receives it, but B will still receive it

but going by the spec, and assuming that it was clear that dedicated worker B stays alive – postMessage() posts a task on B's event loop, so assuming that A dies after the postMessage call finishes, it can die before B receives it, but B will still receive it
